newsitem.title: UK: Refinery margins climb in March, Asia still leads.
newsitem.headline: Refinery margins climb in March, Asia still leads.

text.p: Oil refinery margins in Singapore have shed over 50 cents a barrel in recent days but are still much more healthy than profits in the West.
During March, refiners in all regions consolidated the recovery made from low points hit over the past three months, according to Reuters price data using standard product yields.
A complex refinery in Singapore is returning $4.53 a barrel refining Dubai crude while similar plants in the West running regional crude oils make around $2 a barrel.
A week ago, Singapore refiners were making around $5.25 a barrel while profits have averaged $5.19 during March.

The drop in Singapore reflects a sharp drop in the premium for gasoline over Dubai crude. The premium has dropped over $1 a barrel since the end of last week to below $9 a barrel after peaking at $11.49 in mid-March.
Gas oil also lost ground against crude oil but fuel remains broadly unchanged around $3.50 a barrel below the value of Dubai.
In the West, refinery profitability has also slipped slightly in recent days but the upward trend seen during March remains intact.
In Rotterdam complex plants running Brent make just under $2 a barrel and averaged $2.04 last week.
Hydroskimming plants managed to a turn in a profit last week of 62 cents a barrel having been running at a loss since the middle of February.

Mediterranean refiners showed a similar pattern. Complex plants running Urals were off last week's highs but at $2.26 a barrel were well above lows of just four cents a barrel seen at the end of January.
In the U.S. Gulf, refiners make profits of $1.93 a barrel running Brent and $1.15 running West Texas Intermediate (WTI), according to the price data.
Brent averaged $2.11 last week but WTI is above last week's average of $1.03.
This compares with 48 cents and zero cents respectively in the first week of March.
